Pluely: The Open Source AI Assistant That's 27x Lighter Than Cluely

Dec 31, 2025
Vibe Sparking

In the world of AI meeting assistants, one name has been making waves: Cluely. Marketed as the “#1 Undetectable AI for Meetings,” Cluely raised $15M in funding to build a stealth AI assistant that helps you during meetings, interviews, and conversations—completely invisibly.

But what if you want the same powerful features without the proprietary lock-in, the hefty price tag, or the 270MB application size?

Enter Pluely—the open-source alternative that’s just 10MB, privacy-first, and built for the community.

Why Pluely Matters

Section titled “Why Pluely Matters”

Pluely represents a growing movement in the AI space: open-source, privacy-first alternatives to commercial AI tools. As developers and users become increasingly concerned about data privacy, vendor lock-in, and bloated applications, projects like Pluely offer a compelling alternative.

The Numbers Don’t Lie

Section titled “The Numbers Don’t Lie”
FeaturePluely (Open Source)Cluely (Proprietary)
App Size~10MB~270MB
Size Difference27x smallerBaseline
Compute Usage50% less CPU/RAMHeavy resource usage
Startup Time<100msSeveral seconds
Privacy100% local with your LLMData sent to servers
CostFree & Open SourceCommercial pricing
LicenseGPL-3.0Proprietary

Source: Pluely GitHub

Built with Tauri: Why It Matters

Section titled “Built with Tauri: Why It Matters”

Pluely is built with Tauri, a modern framework for building desktop applications using web technologies. This architectural choice is significant:

Tauri vs Electron Performance

Section titled “Tauri vs Electron Performance”

Based on 2024-2025 benchmarks:

  • Memory Usage: Tauri uses 50-58% less memory than Electron equivalents
  • Startup Time: Tauri apps launch in under 500ms vs ~4 seconds for Electron
  • Bundle Size: Tauri produces substantially smaller bundles by using native OS webview components instead of bundling Chromium

Sources:

  • Tauri vs Electron Comparison
  • Tauri vs Electron 2025 Comparison

Why This Matters for Users

Section titled “Why This Matters for Users”

For an AI assistant that needs to run constantly in the background:

  1. Less battery drain on laptops
  2. More resources available for other applications
  3. Instant startup when you need quick answers
  4. Smaller downloads and updates

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

1. Invisibility Mode

Section titled “1. Invisibility Mode”

Pluely’s signature feature is its translucent overlay window that sits above all other applications. This makes it:

  • Invisible in video calls (Zoom, Google Meet, Teams, Slack)
  • Undetectable in screen shares and recordings
  • Screenshot-proof by design
  • Perfectly stealthy during interviews and presentations

2. Real-Time Audio Capture

Section titled “2. Real-Time Audio Capture”

The system audio capture feature allows you to:

  • Record audio directly from your computer’s output
  • Transcribe meetings in real-time
  • Use voice activity detection for efficient processing

3. Multi-Provider AI Support

Section titled “3. Multi-Provider AI Support”

Unlike many alternatives that lock you into one provider, Pluely supports:

Pre-configured Providers:

  • OpenAI (GPT models)
  • Anthropic (Claude)
  • Google (Gemini)
  • xAI (Grok)
  • Mistral AI
  • Cohere
  • Perplexity
  • Groq
  • Ollama (local models)

Custom Providers: Add any LLM provider using curl commands with full flexibility for authentication, streaming, and response parsing.

4. Voice Input & Screenshots

Section titled “4. Voice Input & Screenshots”
  • Voice Input: Record and convert speech to text using multiple STT providers (OpenAI Whisper, ElevenLabs, Groq, etc.)
  • Screenshot Capture: Full screen or selection mode with manual or automatic AI processing
  • File Attachments: Attach documents, images, and code files for AI analysis

Privacy-First Architecture

Section titled “Privacy-First Architecture”

In an era where data privacy is paramount, Pluely takes a fundamentally different approach:

Local Data Storage

Section titled “Local Data Storage”
  • Conversations: Stored locally in SQLite on your device
  • Settings: Stored in browser localStorage, never transmitted
  • Credentials: Encrypted secure storage for API keys
  • No Telemetry: Zero analytics, usage tracking, or data collection

Direct API Connections

Section titled “Direct API Connections”

Pluely makes API calls directly from your device to your chosen AI provider:

  • No proxy servers
  • No middleware
  • No data collection
  • Verifiable via browser developer tools

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”

Pluely shines in scenarios where you need AI assistance without detection:

  1. Job Interviews: Get real-time information and suggestions
  2. Sales Calls: Access product details instantly while maintaining professionalism
  3. Technical Meetings: Reference documentation without breaking flow
  4. Educational Presentations: Learning assistance that’s invisible to your audience
  5. Design Reviews: Analyze screenshots and get suggestions
  6. Live Coding: Debug code with syntax help in stealth mode

Installation and Usage

Section titled “Installation and Usage”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Node.js (v18 or higher)
  • Rust (latest stable)
  • npm or yarn
  • Tauri prerequisites for your platform

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

This creates platform-specific installers:

  • macOS: .dmg
  • Windows: .msi, .exe
  • Linux: .deb, .rpm, .AppImage

The Competitive Landscape

Section titled “The Competitive Landscape”

Pluely isn’t the only player in the invisible AI assistant space. Other alternatives include:

  • LockedInAI: Desktop app for stealth interview assistance
  • Final Round AI: Coaching for job interviews with video call integration
  • Beyz AI: Stealth mode for technical and behavioral questions

However, Pluely distinguishes itself through:

  • Open source transparency (GPL-3.0 license)
  • Extremely small footprint (10MB vs competitors’ 100MB+)
  • Multi-provider flexibility (not locked into one AI service)
  • Active development with regular releases

Sources:

  • Cluely Alternatives 2025
  • Cluely Alternatives - Fellow

Ethical Considerations

Section titled “Ethical Considerations”

It’s worth addressing the elephant in the room: the ethics of invisible AI assistance.

Several sources note these tools can be used for “cheating in live conversations,” which raises legitimate concerns about:

  • Academic integrity during online exams
  • Professional authenticity in job interviews
  • Fairness in competitive scenarios

Pluely and similar tools are powerful, and with power comes responsibility. The open-source nature of Pluely at least provides transparency—you can inspect exactly what the software does, unlike proprietary black-box alternatives.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Pluely represents an important trend in AI development: the move toward transparent, privacy-first, open-source alternatives to commercial offerings. Its 27x smaller footprint than Cluely demonstrates that you don’t need bloated software to deliver powerful features.

Whether you choose to use Pluely or not, its existence pushes the industry toward:

  • Better privacy practices
  • More efficient software architecture
  • Greater user control
  • Open standards over lock-in

The AI assistant wars are just getting started, and open-source projects like Pluely are ensuring users have a choice.

pg-aiguide: AI-Optimized PostgreSQL Expertise for Coding Assistants

Dec 31, 2025
Vibe Sparking

pg-aiguide: AI-Optimized PostgreSQL Expertise for Coding Assistants

Section titled “pg-aiguide: AI-Optimized PostgreSQL Expertise for Coding Assistants”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI-powered development tools, one challenge has persisted: AI coding assistants often generate database code that is outdated, missing critical constraints, unaware of modern PostgreSQL features, and inconsistent with real-world best practices.

Enter pg-aiguide – an innovative MCP server and Claude plugin developed by Timescale (now Tiger Data) that provides AI-optimized PostgreSQL expertise to coding assistants.

What is pg-aiguide?

Section titled “What is pg-aiguide?”

pg-aiguide is an open-source tool (Apache-2.0 licensed) that helps AI coding tools write dramatically better PostgreSQL code. It provides three core capabilities:

  1. Semantic Search across the official PostgreSQL manual (version-aware)
  2. AI-Optimized Skills – curated, opinionated Postgres best practices used automatically by AI agents
  3. Extension Ecosystem Docs, starting with TimescaleDB, with more extensions coming soon

The Problem pg-aiguide Solves

Section titled “The Problem pg-aiguide Solves”

AI coding tools frequently generate PostgreSQL code that suffers from several issues:

  • Outdated syntax – not keeping up with modern PostgreSQL versions
  • Missing constraints and indexes – leading to poor data integrity and performance
  • Unaware of modern PG features – missing out on capabilities introduced in recent versions
  • Inconsistent with best practices – not following proven patterns from experienced developers

Real-World Impact

Section titled “Real-World Impact”

The pg-aiguide team conducted an impressive comparison test. When asked to create an e-commerce database schema:

  • 4× more constraints compared to AI without pg-aiguide
  • 55% more indexes (including partial and expression indexes)
  • PG17-recommended patterns – using the latest PostgreSQL features
  • Modern features like GENERATED ALWAYS AS IDENTITY and NULLS NOT DISTINCT
  • Cleaner naming & documentation – more maintainable code

Installation & Setup

Section titled “Installation & Setup”

pg-aiguide can be used in two ways:

As a Public MCP Server

Section titled “As a Public MCP Server”

Available at https://mcp.tigerdata.com/docs, it can be configured for any AI coding agent:

As a Claude Code Plugin

Section titled “As a Claude Code Plugin”

For Claude Code users, installation is straightforward:

Supported AI Tools

Section titled “Supported AI Tools”

pg-aiguide supports a wide range of AI coding environments:

  • Claude Code – Native plugin support
  • Cursor – One-click install available
  • Gemini CLI – MCP server integration
  • VS Code / VS Code Insiders – Command-line installation
  • Windsurf – Configuration-based setup
  • Codex – MCP server integration

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

Semantic Documentation Search

Section titled “Semantic Documentation Search”

The semantic_search_postgres_docs function performs semantic search over the official PostgreSQL manual, with results scoped to specific Postgres versions. This means AI agents get accurate, version-relevant information.

Extension Ecosystem Support

Section titled “Extension Ecosystem Support”

Through semantic_search_tiger_docs, pg-aiguide searches Tiger Data’s documentation corpus, including TimescaleDB and future ecosystem extensions.

Curated Best Practices

Section titled “Curated Best Practices”

The view_skill function exposes opinionated PostgreSQL best-practice skills covering:

  • Schema design patterns
  • Indexing strategies
  • Data type selection
  • Data integrity and constraints
  • Naming conventions
  • Performance tuning
  • Modern PostgreSQL features

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”

Simple Schema Design

Section titled “Simple Schema Design”

Prompt: “Create a Postgres table schema for storing usernames and unique email addresses.”

pg-aiguide helps generate properly constrained schemas with appropriate indexes and modern PostgreSQL types.

Complex IoT Schema

Section titled “Complex IoT Schema”

For more complex scenarios, like an IoT device monitoring system:

“Generate a Postgres schema for an IoT device company. Devices collect environmental data including temperature, humidity, pressure, and other measurements. Each device has a unique ID and human-readable name. Analysis includes finding outliers, anomalies, and device-specific ad-hoc analysis.”

pg-aiguide helps design schemas optimized for both recent data analysis and historical reporting.

Technology Stack

Section titled “Technology Stack”
  • Python (66.5%) – Core server logic
  • TypeScript (23.1%) – Plugin integrations
  • JavaScript (9.3%) – Web interfaces

Future Plans

Section titled “Future Plans”

The project has an ambitious roadmap:

  • pgvector support for vector similarity search
  • PostGIS for geospatial data
  • Community contributions for additional extensions

Contributing

Section titled “Contributing”

pg-aiguide welcomes contributions in several areas:

  • New Postgres best-practice skills
  • Additional documentation corpora
  • Search quality improvements
  • Bug reports and feature ideas

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

pg-aiguide represents a significant step forward in AI-assisted database development. By providing AI agents with deep, versioned PostgreSQL knowledge and proven patterns, it bridges the gap between AI-generated code and production-quality database schemas.

Whether you’re a developer using AI coding assistants or a team building AI-powered development tools, pg-aiguide offers a practical solution to the persistent problem of suboptimal AI-generated database code.

Section titled “Links”

Apple App Store Review Rejection: A Painful Lesson from Carelessly Submitting the Wrong Version

Dec 31, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Apple App Store Review Rejection: A Painful Lesson from Carelessly Submitting the Wrong Version

Section titled “Apple App Store Review Rejection: A Painful Lesson from Carelessly Submitting the Wrong Version”

“Double-check your submission version. Don’t let carelessness ruin your hard work.” — A painful lesson learned.

As an iOS developer, the App Store review process is challenging enough. But the most frustrating rejections aren’t due to code bugs or design issues—they’re due to your own carelessness.

Today I want to share a lesson that left me full of regret.

Background: Resubmitting After UI Fixes

Section titled “Background: Resubmitting After UI Fixes”

In a previous article, I documented the entire process of using Google Antigravity to fix App Store review issues for MoneyMind. After much effort, I finally fixed all the flagged UI problems:

  • Hidden the non-functional edit icon
  • Fixed the text overlay issue
  • Ensured page style consistency

Full of confidence, I prepared a new version and resubmitted for review.

First Resubmission

Section titled “First Resubmission”

After receiving Apple’s review issue email, I followed the standard submission process:

  1. Open Xcode
  2. Update version number
  3. Archive the project
  4. Upload to App Store Connect
  5. Fill in review information

Everything seemed smooth, and I awaited the review results with anticipation.

The Email Returned: Same Issues

Section titled “The Email Returned: Same Issues”

A few days later, when I saw that familiar Apple email again, my heart sank.

Same review team, same rejection reasons, same UI issue screenshots.

How could this be? I clearly fixed all the issues!

The Truth: Submitted the Wrong Version

Section titled “The Truth: Submitted the Wrong Version”

When I logged into App Store Connect and carefully examined the submitted version, the truth made me want to hide:

The version I submitted didn’t contain any fixes at all!

In my haste, I didn’t carefully check:

  • Whether the submitted Build version corresponded to the fixed code
  • Didn’t do a final Smoke Test before submission
  • Didn’t carefully verify the consistency between Git commit and Xcode Archive

Damage Assessment

Section titled “Damage Assessment”

This careless error brought real losses:

Time Cost

Section titled “Time Cost”
  • Lost a valuable review opportunity (usually takes 1-3 days)
  • Need to requeue for a new review
  • Delayed the release of the bug fix version to users

Opportunity Cost

Section titled “Opportunity Cost”
  • Users continue using the version with UI issues
  • Affected app user experience and ratings
  • Missed potential version promotion timing

Mental Burden

Section titled “Mental Burden”
  • Self-blame and regret
  • Potentially leaving a bad impression on Apple’s review team
  • Lost confidence in my own workflow

How to Avoid the Same Mistake

Section titled “How to Avoid the Same Mistake”

From this lesson, I’ve compiled a pre-submission checklist to help other developers avoid the same error:

1. Version Verification Checklist

Section titled “1. Version Verification Checklist”

2. Create Verification Scripts

Section titled “2. Create Verification Scripts”

To ensure the submitted version is correct, I wrote a simple verification script:

3. Record Submission Information

Section titled “3. Record Submission Information”

Create a submission record document for each submission:

Submitting the Correct Version and Explaining

Section titled “Submitting the Correct Version and Explaining”

After discovering the error, I immediately took the following actions:

  1. Re-Archive the correct code version
  2. Upload new Build to App Store Connect
  3. Honestly explain the situation in review information

In the review information, I wrote:

“Dear Apple Review Team:

In my previous submission, I mistakenly uploaded the wrong version without the fixes. This submission includes all fixed issues:

  1. Hidden the non-functional edit icon
  2. Fixed text overlay issues
  3. Ensured page style consistency with other pages

I sincerely apologize for the extra work this caused. Thank you for your understanding.”

Being honest about the mistake is better than pretending nothing happened. Apple’s review team is human too—they understand that developers make mistakes.

Lessons Learned

Section titled “Lessons Learned”

This experience made me deeply realize:

  1. Carefulness is the most important quality — Technical skills can be learned, but carelessness requires constant vigilance
  2. Processes are more reliable than trust — Establish strict checklists, don’t rely on “it should be fine”
  3. Verification is a necessary step — Always verify your version before submitting
  4. Honesty when facing mistakes — If you make a mistake, admit it honestly and correct it

Advice for Other Developers

Section titled “Advice for Other Developers”

If you’re preparing an App Store submission, remember:

  1. Slow is fast — Spending 10 extra minutes checking is better than wasting days on re-review
  2. Trust your checklist — Even for simple tasks, confirm each item
  3. Document everything — Keep records of each submission for easy traceability
  4. Don’t be overconfident — Even experienced developers make mistakes

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

While this App Store rejection experience was painful, it was also a valuable lesson. It reminded me that in software development, technical ability is only part of success—meticulousness and a rigorous attitude are equally important.

I hope my story helps other developers avoid the same mistake. Remember: Double-check your submission version. Don’t let carelessness ruin your hard work.

Wishing everyone smooth App Store reviews!

Superagent: AI Guardrails for Secure and Compliant Agents

Dec 31, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Superagent: AI Guardrails for Secure and Compliant Agents

Section titled “Superagent: AI Guardrails for Secure and Compliant Agents”

As AI agents and chatbots become integral to business operations, ensuring their security and compliance has never been more critical. Enter Superagent – an open-source guardrail system that provides purpose-trained models to secure AI applications in real-time.

The Challenge of AI Safety

Section titled “The Challenge of AI Safety”

Building production AI applications introduces unique security challenges:

  • Prompt injection attacks that can hijack agent behavior
  • Hallucinations that spread misinformation
  • Data leaks through inadvertent PII/PHI exposure
  • Compliance violations across regulatory frameworks
  • Tool abuse where agents execute unauthorized actions

Traditional approaches using general-purpose LLMs for safety checks introduce latency and lack the precision needed for production environments.

What is Superagent?

Section titled “What is Superagent?”

Superagent provides three purpose-trained models that work together to secure AI applications:

Guard

Section titled “Guard”

Threat Detection with 98% Accuracy

Guard detects and blocks unsafe inputs before they reach your models:

  • Prompt injections and jailbreak attempts
  • Malicious tool calls
  • Backdoors and adversarial inputs
  • Unsafe content generation

According to Superagent’s benchmarks, Guard outperforms GPT-4, Gemini 2.5 Pro, and other frontier models in threat detection – without the latency penalty of running a full LLM for safety checks.

Verify

Section titled “Verify”

Output Validation and Grounding

Verify grounds and validates model outputs against enterprise sources:

  • Fact-checking against internal documents
  • Policy compliance verification
  • Consistency validation
  • Hallucination prevention

Every generation is validated before reaching users, ensuring factual accuracy and policy alignment.

Redact

Section titled “Redact”

Real-Time Data Protection

Redact removes sensitive data from text and documents:

  • PII (Personally Identifiable Information)
  • PHI (Protected Health Information)
  • API keys and secrets
  • Custom sensitive patterns

Privacy and compliance are maintained across AI inputs and outputs without manual review.

Architecture and Performance

Section titled “Architecture and Performance”

Low-Latency Design

Section titled “Low-Latency Design”

Unlike general-purpose LLMs used for safety, Superagent’s models are purpose-trained for specific security tasks, enabling:

  • Sub-millisecond response times for Guard checks
  • Minimal overhead on AI workflows
  • High-throughput processing for enterprise scale

Open Source Foundation

Section titled “Open Source Foundation”

Superagent is MIT-licensed with 10K+ GitHub stars, providing:

  • Self-hosting capabilities
